prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Single position at 85, 86.87, 97.12, and 98.99 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Single position observations with 0.5" angular resolution with four bands of 1.875 GHz centered at 85, 86.87, 97.12 and 98.99 GHz.
The frequency bands covered by this goal are: 84062.5-85937.5 MHz 85932.5-87807.5 MHz 96182.5-98057.5 MHz 98052.5-99927.5 MHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The proposed observations correspond to a line survey at 3mm. Large instantaneous frequency coverage together with a suitable spectral resolution are needed, which justify the required data rate. The requested spectral resolution is mandatory to resolve the different regions of the envelope. The lines arising from the dust formation zone will have linewidths of 4-5 km/s at half intensity. The lines formed in the external layers will have a velocity coverage of 29 km/s. Thus, to properly resolve the lines from the dust formation zone, a velocity resolution better than ~2 km/s is needed, only achieved at band 3 by using single polarization.
The requested sensitivity for unresolved structures is 3 mJy/beam per 0.5 MHz channel. It corresponds to a sensitivity of 2.0 K for a beam of 0.5". For lines arising from the dust formation zone (r<0.5") brightness temperatures as large as 100-1000 K are expected. Hence, the signal to noise ratio for the emission arising around the star will be >35. Features from this zone as weak as 10 K (15 mJy) will be detected with a S/N of ~4-5 (see Figure 3).
The data will be weighted, if needed, to decrease the angular resolutiom to 1 and 2" in order to increase the sensitivity over the carbon-chain radicals ring which has a radius of 14" and a tickness of 4". Structures of a few arcseconds in size are expected as shown by the Plateau de Bure maps (see Figure 2). The requested 3 mJy/beam per 0.5 MHz channels will correspond to a sensitivity of 0.5 and 0.13 K for 1 and 2 arcsecond beams respectively (see Table 1). The most abundant radicals, CCH, C3H, C4H, C5H and C6H, together with their anions, cyanopolyynes HC3N and HC5N, abundant molecules as CS, SiO, SiS could be easily detected. Silicon-carbon and Sulfur-carbon clusters, SiC2, SiCCC, SiC4, CCS, CCCS, will also be mapped.
The total observing time for this goal is 1.77h.
ACA observations are not needed to achieve the aims of this proposal, as indicated by the OT and shown by our previous observations with the PdBI interferometer. In addition, a sensitive line survey of the 80-116 GHz band was carried out of a 2'x2' region, with the 30m IRAM telescope, and will provide complementary information about the extended envelope components that are out of the scope of this proposal.
In order to guarantee a good coverage and check the consistency of the data between spectral windows some overlapping is desirable, which is not provided by the Spectral Scan mode. The frequency bands covered by this goal are: 84062.5-85937.5 MHz 85932.5-87807.5 MHz 96182.5-98057.5 MHz 98052.5-99927.5 MHz

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Single Position at 88.74, 90.61, 100.86 and 102.73 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Single position observations with 0.5" angular resolution with four bands of 1.875 GHz centered at 88.74, 90.61, 100.86 and 102.73 GHz.
The frequency bands covered by this goal are: 87802.5- 89677.5 MHz 89672.5- 91547.5 MHz 99922.5-101797.5 MHz 101792.5-103667.5 MHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The proposed observations correspond to a line survey at 3mm. Large instantaneous frequency coverage together with a suitable spectral resolution are needed, which justify the required data rate. The requested spectral resolution is mandatory to resolve the different regions of the envelope. The lines arising from the dust formation zone will have linewidths of 4-5 km/s at half intensity. The lines formed in the external layers will have a velocity coverage of 29 km/s. Thus, to properly resolve the lines from the dust formation zone, a velocity resolution better than ~2 km/s is needed, only achieved at band 3 by using single polarization.
The requested sensitivity for unresolved structures is 3 mJy/beam per 0.5 MHz channel. It corresponds to a sensitivity of 1.9 K for a beam of 0.5". For lines arising from the dust formation zone (r<0.5") brightness temperatures as large as 100-1000 K are expected. Silicon-carbon and Sulfur-carbon clusters, SiC2, SiCCC, SiC4, CCS, CCCS, will also be mapped.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Single position 96.22, 98.09, 108.34, and 110.21 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Single position observations with 0.45" angular resolution with four bands of 1.875 GHz centered at 96.22, 98.09, 108.34, and 110.21 GHz.
The frequency bands covered by this goal are: 95282.5- 97157.5 MHz 97152.5- 99027.5 MHz 107402.5-109277.5 MHz 109272.5-111147.5 MHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The proposed observations correspond to a line survey at 3mm. Large instantaneous frequency coverage together with a suitable spectral resolution are needed, which justify the required data rate. The requested spectral resolution is mandatory to resolve the different regions of the envelope. The lines arising from the dust formation zone will have linewidths of 4-5 km/s at half intensity. The lines formed in the external layers will have a velocity coverage of 29 km/s. Thus, to properly resolve the lines from the dust formation zone, a velocity resolution better than ~2 km/s is needed, only achieved at band 3 by using single polarization.
The requested sensitivity for unresolved structures is 4 mJy/beam per 0.5 MHz channel. It corresponds to a sensitivity of 2.6 K for a beam of 0.45". For lines arising from the dust formation zone (r<0.5") brightness temperatures as large as 100-1000 K are expected. Hence, the signal to noise ratio for the emission arising around the star will be >35. Features from this zone as weak as 10 K (15 mJy) will be detected with a S/N of ~4-5 (see Figure 3).
The data will be weighted, if needed, to decrease the angular resolutiom to 1 and 2" in order to increase the sensitivity over the carbon-chain radicals ring which has a radius of 14" and a tickness of 4". Structures of a few arcseconds in size are expected as shown by the Plateau de Bure maps (see Figure 2). The requested 4 mJy/beam per 0.5 MHz channels will correspond to a sensitivity of 0.53 and 0.13 K for 1 and 2 arcsecond beams respectively (see Table 1). The most abundant radicals, CCH, C3H, C4H, C5H and C6H, together with their anions, cyanopolyynes HC3N and HC5N, abundant molecules as CS, SiO, SiS, 13CO, C18O could be easily detected. Silicon-carbon and Sulfur-carbon clusters, SiC2, SiCCC, SiC4, CCS, CCCS, will also be mapped.
The total observing time for this goal is 1.33h.
ACA observations are not needed to achieve the aims of this proposal, as indicated by the OT and shown by our previous observations with the PdBI interferometer. In addition, a sensitive line survey of the 80-116 GHz band was carried out of a 2'x2' region, with the 30m IRAM telescope, and will provide complementary information about the extended envelope components that are out of the scope of this proposal.
In order to guarantee a good coverage and check the consistency of the data between spectral windows some overlapping is desirable, which is not provided by the Spectral Scan mode. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
IRC+10216 is a carbon rich evolved star in which more than 50% of molecules known in space have been detected. While a few diatomic and triatomic molecules are formed in the innermost regions of the circumstellar envelope, long carbon-chain radicals, metal-bearing cyanides, and other complex molecules are formed in an external ring, 14" in radius, where chemistry is dominated by UV photons and reactions between radicals and neutral species.
Recent ALMA cycle0 observations at 270 GHz (Cernicharo et al., 2013) have shown the presence of hundreds of unidentified and intense lines arising from the dust formation zone. The carriers of these lines are certainly participating in the nucleation and growth of dust grains.
We propose to carry out a sensitive line survey at 3mm with the following goals : 1) To fully characterize the molecular composition of the dust formation zone. 2) To fully characterize from several transitions of C4H, C5H, C6H, C7H, and their anions, the physical and chemical composition of the molecular ring where these species are formed. 3) To study the spatial distribution of the gas from the innermost regions (0.4") to the external chemically rich ring at r=14".
